Evie awesome well thank you everyone for inviting me to your meeting it's a
pleasure that I have the opportunity to merge together a lot of content around
presentations that I've given on this topic um several times in fact some of
it's from keynotes I've given at KCD DC um where Katherine and I hung out last
year as well as uh keynotes on the CubeCon stage but this is my first time
putting this all together for you all um in this kind of format i've been asked
to talk to you about getting into opensource particularly if you are not familiar with a given piece of
technology or even open source communities because they can be very daunting they can be very difficult to
navigate and hard to understand about how to approach them in a way that allows you to feel included and to
pursue more and increasing involvement within those ecosystems and the first thing that I
want to say regarding open source communities getting involved is you should always approach them from the
perspective of leaving them better than you found them in open source we have a
lot of work and not a lot of people and the people that are actively involved in
projects generally don't have a lot of time so your presence in anything that
you can do to help them out to make their lives just a little bit easier
whether or not that's triaging tickets in the GitHub queue or even answering
questions in a Slack channel is always helpful and these things assist project
maintainers they assist other community members that come behind you so when you're approaching a new project or a
new community group consider where you can make changes that improve it for the
next person behind you there's this wonderful quote that
I've reused multiple times from Forest Brazil that talks about the fundamentals
of what open source is random people on the internet anonymously creating
critically important software in their spare time and companies make billions
of dollars on this using it for free and oh by the way it will happen to be shelf
stable for decades a lot of the original open-source software from the '9s is
still around and in widespread use today in fact many of those maintainers are either still maintaining those projects
or they've begun planning a succession for who the next maintainer is to come behind them and this is kind of the
magic of how open- source actually works it's people that you meet online maybe
in person on occasion and they're working towards a goal or an objective
that is greater than themselves they're doing so in a manner that doesn't
require them to expect payment that doesn't ex require them to expect anything in return other than
camaraderie and community and that feeling that you've been able to accomplish something beyond
yourself and there's a few key principles associated with open source and being involved in these communities
and groups i've captured the four main ones that I usually focus on but there
are a lot more and depending on which open source community you get involved in you'll see some that are more
specific you'll see some that are more general but above all it's transparency
open source is based on the fact that the source code is available to you without payment that you can go and
independently inspect that codebase to understand how it works and in recent
years that's expanded beyond just source code to include the documentation
tutorials how-to guides installation instructions even explanations about how
the software works in the form of presentations at public conferences the
recording of that material and so much more and through that transparency we
can enable open exchange and collaboration on ideas if we can see the source code and we can see the
documentation we can ask questions publicly about it we can improve our understanding of that software come up
with new ideas on how to make it better how to improve it how to make it more
approachable for an enduser or an adopter in a way that reduces the barrier to entry for them and that's the
same thing for the community groups and the governance that go along with these projects
a lot of open source is also based on meritocracy but a lot of people get that kind of mixed up it's not necessarily
about whether or not you're a technical expert in Kubernetes networking or maybe that you're a security expert in
open-source it's the fact that you showed up and you put in the work and
you did so in a way that invites others to come along beside you so while it is
based on your technical skill set initially what you're doing is you're building rapport within a community to
be a reliable and trustworthy community member through consistent involvement
either in meetings or in code contributions or discussions in Slack
and even improving documentation it's your knowhow and your approach and
your practices in that approach that allow you to go beyond the technical skill set that you initially came in
with and when you're doing it in this manner it allows you to build your technical skills as a secondary function
of why you're really there which is to leave it better than you found it and
finally and certainly not the least important is that open source communities are just that they're
communitydriven they're based on who shows up provides the ideas and puts in
the work you can show up and have a great idea but if you never come back to
follow through with it it often isn't picked up so if you want to see something happen you have to make the
commitment to put in the work so let's say that you don't write software and not everyone does that's
okay i am not a programmer i am not a software engineer please don't ask me to
write code it would be absolutely terrible and I'm at a point in my career where it doesn't make sense for me to
write code 8 hours a day especially if there's an expectation it would show up
in a production system that's pretty scary however in order for technology to
reach adoption it requires multiple different types of skills to go from
idea to deployment and eventual upgrade maybe even decommissioning at the end
the key thing in all of this whether you're a software engineer or a program
manager or a community manager is that you understand how it works and there
are a lot of references and material available and if information is missing you can always ask questions and improve
it coding and development while these are the core of technology they don't
actually see the light of day without the support of the community to make them happen to cut their release to
provide the blog post write the release notes and encourage and uh and meet with
adopters so that they can understand how it works and gather that feedback to continue improving these projects and
communities but let's say you kind of understand open source now but you don't quite get
cloud native we are in CNCF after all there are a ton of resources that are
available online and while that's true it can be difficult to understand where to go look each one of our technical
advisory groups has a YouTube channel our projects also record several of
their community meetings these are great sources of information about what the current pulse and happenings are
associated with a project or a community group cubecons are another excellent
resource but it's not available to everyone we understand there are travel expectations there's a financial cost
associated with it that's not available for everyone so going and looking at the
YouTube recordings of past CubeCon presentations is a great way for you to become a little bit more familiar with
specific concepts associated with open source projects or how different open-source cloudnative projects can
work together to assist adopters in achieving a particular outcome it's just a matter of finding something that's of
interest to you attending community meetings such as this one is another great way and asking questions about
what's happening you can always and I encourage everyone to look at the repos
of projects sometimes they're really wellkept and upto-date they have a lot
of material information in there for you when is the community meeting where is their Slack channel what is their rad
latest release what is the project planning in the next upcoming release and what is the roadmap beyond that into
the future you can get a wealth of information from those project repositories and if it's not in a
repository most projects have documentation that explained how they work and this is always an area that
projects are seeking improvement so that their adopters can understand a little bit more about how the project or the
technology functions but specifically for cloud native the technical oversight
committee maintains the definition of cloud native and it's not super detailed
it's not super granular but it does have a few important concepts and principles that we apply to cloudnative
technologies such as it's scalable it's programmatic it's repeatable that these
technologies and systems are loosely coupled meaning I can have several
independent components that all work together against a standardized API we
also ensure that our cloudnative projects are secure resilient to changes
as they occur in those native environments that they're manageable in an automated fashion and that they're
sustainable as well as observable so you know what's going on in your environment the reason why we have all
of these principles and concepts in cloud native is because there's benefits to them when you have robust automation
you can employ cloudnative practices and make changes in your environment faster
at the velocity that your business or your organization needs having loosely
coupled systems allows us to more uniquely and independently expect those individual components while also taking
a step back and looking at the bigger picture about how they all work together
but there's a lot of challenges when we approach these kinds of things both in open source and in cloud native expect
it to take about a year to really get involved in a project these projects in
some cases are massive sometimes they're really small and they don't have a lot of information so it'll take time to get
to know them you have to rely on existing guidance and documentation which sometimes they're up to date and
that's great and sometimes they're not so be clear when you're asking questions about what you're referring to if
something isn't clear every project also has its own culture and its own goals
and objectives sometimes observing those community meetings those community groups is a great way to get an
understanding for the relationship dynamics and the culture that each project has if you can finding a buddy a
shadow or a mentor maybe even another new person in the group that you can collaborate with as you are both
approaching the project together to learn more about it and how you can contribute understanding how that
project fits in within the larger picture of cloud native how adopters might use it to address their use cases
is also beneficial it gives you a more concrete understanding of what the goals and objectives of the project actually
are and doing this allows you to approach the project with some form of
commonality you're seeking understanding the basics of how it works and from that initial understanding is how you're
going to approach other aspects of your engagement and contributions with the project you can't assume that everybody
in the project has the same experience as each other or as you so you need to
feel out and find out from individuals what their role is how long they've been
involved what they're currently working on this is one way of starting to expand your network and you should always check
your assumptions what you currently do in your company for your business isn't
always going to be the same thing that shows up in open source what works for your company or organization is probably
not going to work in an open source project so it's important that you take that time and understand the culture and
the objectives and the governance of a community before you we start making changes within it emily just one second

go ahead thank you yeah and your approach in as you do this is come with it with a learning mindset you

what the goals and objectives of the project are with where your personal interests may be in that

is just try and I know that's very difficult and tricky because there isn't a checklist or a procedure document that

how could I potentially get involved here where might there be opportunities or gaps how can I lead within this group
what does that opportunity look like what does that pathway look like for me and how can I collaborate better with
these individuals whose culture or processes might be different than what I'm used
to in order to answer a lot of these questions you need to know what you're passionate about it might not be
specific to technology it might be I want to make a whole bunch of new friends within CNCF or I want to expand
my network in this particular area so I can draw on those other individuals strengths to complement my own be
curious you don't always know what it is that you care about until you've learned
a lot of different things so be open ask more questions test some assumptions
with that community or project group and ask for help you're here and you're
interested in doing something anything don't be afraid to try what
opportunities come to you they might be small things like fixing spelling on a
documentation website it might be suggesting improvements to a project's triage process or it might just be
volunteering to learn on the fly and this is how you expand your
network actually just showing up is a lot people will get to know you and know what it work it is that you're doing
within a project or group they'll start asking you questions and you can do the same of others ask what it is that
they're working on why they're doing it and what they're interested in when you volunteer for things be very clear that
you're still learning and you might need some assistance are they okay with you reaching out with questions and don't be
afraid to ask for 15 minutes with group leaders chairs or maintainers to learn their story why they're involved in a
project and share yours and above all be present and that is the end of my

yes it's always okay to approach them um for myself my first journey into
open-source and ultimately cloud native was attending a presentation at a
conference at CubeCon and asking a question because I couldn't believe what I heard that they were doing security
assessments on open source projects it was unheard of and I had so many questions well how are you doing that
how does that work what is the level of effort is this something that I could potentially get involved in be curious
that's the first thing be genuine in your interest about a particular topic because you're seeking to understand and
then assess whether or not it aligns with your interests the response I got back from the individual when I started
asking those questions was "Well why don't you show up to one of our meetings?" And that's how I kind of got
involved i asked more questions in the meeting than I got answers for and then I spent time going to TAG Security's
repository and reading through all of their documentation and then learning that well if I want to see changes to
the documentation it's not just enough for me to ask questions to have it changed I need to be the change agent
myself because what'll end up happening is if I file a pull request which is not
code it's just documentation on the repository and I get something wrong
there's pull request reviewers that are going to look at it and say this is wrong and this is wrong and this is wrong and as long as I'm positive in my
re-engagement on to make those changes because I see these as learning opportunities for myself that PR is
eventually going to get merged into the repo and then I've got one thing done and I can go back think about my other
questions I've had and make more changes and more suggestions it might be filing
an issue on a repo or it might be understanding how the pull request process actually works more because
maybe it's not documented for the project and it's causing me some confusion in the PR so this is where
asking those open-ended questions is very helpful so that you get more information back did that answer your
question Rob yep thank you and Milad and Matt have
questions matt can go first milad says "Um what if you don't code at all and
you just have like business skills or marketing skills or other skill sets can you still contribute to open source?"
Yes you can marketing and business skill sets are often the one thing that many open source projects fundamentally lack
unless they're backed by a particular vendor organization and they'll have those people that show up but a lot of
projects struggle with increasing awareness about how awesome the project is what it does and how it can be used
to solve business problems when I do due diligence on projects in CNCF for moving
levels one of the things that I try to look for and I seek out when I have adopter interviews is why they're using
the project what benefits it actually provides them that information helps me as the TOC member understand the
maturity of the project and whether or not adopters find value in it but that information is also helpful for other
adopters to understand how their business peers might be leveraging it and also for the maintainers to bring
that information back in make improvements to the project and understand it more so if you don't have
coding experience reach out to users of the project and understand what it is that they're doing take those insights
and that knowledge back and share that with the maintainers and collaborate on how you could potentially either address
those issues or be more clear in how the project is expected to be used

or scared to contribute because um anyway I completely understand it is
very hard you've asked a lot of questions or you've kind of explained
some areas where you struggle and you're not the only one in CNCF we have a lot of project maintainers that will
disappear they'll just be gone and they don't tell anybody what's happening with them it could be they have a medical
issue that they need to deal with and that could be sudden unplanned and unexpected it occurs but you come back
and you say "Hey sorry i had a medical thing i'm back for right now i might be out again." Being as upfront as you can
about your availability helps set expectations that others can work around
and it's even better if you can identify other community members that you've been mentoring to replace you to fill in that
gap in your absence particularly if you know that maintaining a project project
is getting too difficult for you to do alone you need to bring others in behind you work life balance is always going to
be a challenge but you're in control of your own schedule and as long as you are being very clear hey I only maintain
this project for a couple hours on the weekend don't expect 24/7 support just
being transparent with your community members with your adopters about what to expect always is helpful it's it's being
honest with them as far as time commitments go it really depends like you said on your employer but one of the
things that I recommend community members reach out to their managers and their employers about is time commitment
expectations and trying to stick with that if you're a community member you're not heavily involved in a key role on a
project maybe five to 10 percent of your time is totally okay and then providing
that explanation to your management about how your contributions to an open source project bene benefit you as an
individual at the company versus your company who might be using that project
because they're not always the same your career growth and skills you get in open source contributions can help you and
your team around you because collaboration is the lost art and then
as long as the project aligns with your business's use maybe it's the upstream of a downstream that you're developing
and productizing that's a little bit easier to justify that commitment upstream because you're saving money on
that fork and that patching by doing it upstream first however if you want to go the
maintainership route I try to recommend folks stick with 20% to 25% of their
time and I know it seems like a lot but maintaining a project like you said is a lot of hard work but you need to fix
those times for yourself as a TOC member right now I've dropped my time back to
15 to 20% when I was the chair of the TOC it was closer to 20 to 25 and I felt
terrible when I couldn't fill all of that 25% time took a while for me to be
okay with that because I needed to strike work life balance for myself and it's those little hours that add up over
the course of the week it might be checking Slack messages in the morning to make sure you're not blocking folks
or it might be spending an hour at the end of the day going through and triaging some issues you need to work
through your schedule in a way that works best for you so it doesn't feel so burdensome and be totally okay taking a
step back when it's too much because you can get burnt out as a maintainer and
identifying community members that you can mentor coach and lead into your role will also help you it takes a little bit
more work because you're ramping somebody else new up so you're going to slow down but in the end it helps you
because it allows you to take that vacation you've been looking forward to without fear that something terrible
will happen in your project because you've started to train somebody else up and quite honestly it's just open source
